Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 212,.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over the claims asserted herein pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 212, § 3, in that the damages sought exceed $25,000.

Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 223,.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 223, § 1, because the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Middlesex County, Massachusetts.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a business invitee, a duty of reasonable care to maintain its premises in a safe condition and to protect her from known or reasonably foreseeable dangers. *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 372–73 (2010); *LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.*, 323 Mass. 702, 705 (1949).
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that, under Massachusetts premises liability law, a property owner owes lawful visitors (a category that includes business invitees) a duty to use reasonable care to keep the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them from dangers the owner knows or should know about. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction precisely to apply this general duty of reasonable care to snow and ice, confirming the duty described in the proposition. Although it does not use the phrase “business invitee” in the holding paragraph, it clearly adopts a uniform reasonable-care duty toward all lawful visitors, which encompasses business invitees.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.*.raw_text: *LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.*, 323 Mass. 702, 705 (1949).
*LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.*.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff, a business invitee, a duty of reasonable care to maintain its premises in a safe condition and to protect her from known or reasonably foreseeable dangers. *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368, 372–73 (2010); *LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.*, 323 Mass. 702, 705 (1949).
*LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.*.case_name: LeBlanc v. Atlantic Building & Supply Co.
*LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.*.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the Massachusetts rule that a landowner owes business visitors a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe or at least to warn them of non-obvious dangers known or reasonably knowable to the landowner. Although the court ultimately finds no negligence on the facts, it clearly affirms the duty principle that Papadopoulos later cites and builds on. Thus the case is an appropriate authority for the general invitee-duty proposition quoted.
*LeBlanc v. Atlantic Bldg. & Supply Co.*.relevant_excerpt: "It is a familiar rule that a landowner owes to business visitors a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition for such visitors’ use according to the invitation extended to them, or at least to warn them of dangers not obvious to the ordinary person but which are known or should be known to the landowner. Kelley v. Goldberg, 288 Mass. 79, 81. Sweeny v. Old Colony & Newport Railroad, 10 Allen, 368, 373. Parker v. Jordan Marsh Co. 310 Mass. 227, 229."

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783–785 (2007).
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: A hazardous condition resulting from spilled milk on the floor of the dairy aisle was a reasonably foreseeable danger to customers, including Plaintiff. *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783–785 (2007).
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The case concerns a slip and fall on a grape in a self-service produce area and discusses foreseeability of hazards arising from that mode of operation. It does not involve spilled milk, the dairy aisle, or facts specific to liquid spills, and its holding is framed in general terms about produce and self‑service operations. Using this case as authority for the specific proposition that a milk spill in the dairy aisle was a reasonably foreseeable danger misstates its factual context, even though its general reasoning on foreseeable hazards in self-service stores could be analogized.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “In particular, as is the case here, fruit and vegetable debris presents an obvious risk of injury to a customer, and a reasonably prudent person would not place these items in an aisle or allow them to remain there. Thus, because the determination of reasonableness is a question of fact, the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 169 (1973).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant had actual notice of the dangerous condition, as evidenced by the employee’s statement that he was aware of the spill before Plaintiff’s fall. Alternatively, Defendant had constructive notice of the hazard because the condition had existed for a sufficient period of time that Defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it. *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 169 (1973).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The case discusses when a possessor of premises may be held liable based on actual or constructive notice of a foreign substance, but in Oliveri there was no evidence that any employee had actual knowledge of the substance before the fall. The opinion instead focuses on whether circumstantial evidence (description of the substance and timing) was sufficient to show constructive notice, and ultimately holds it was not, directing judgment for the defendant. Thus, it does not support a proposition that the defendant had actual notice via an employee’s statement, nor does it find constructive notice on similar facts; it instead is largely defense‑favorable precedent on the insufficiency of such proof.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “Where a foreign substance on a floor or stairway causes the business visitor to fall and sustain injuries, he may prove the negligence of the defendant by proof that the defendant or his servant caused the substance to be there, or he may show that the defendant or his servants had actual knowledge of the existence of the foreign substance… In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions were unreasonable and constituted a breach of the duty of care owed to Plaintiff. *Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass. 47, 56 (1983).
*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The cited portion is a dissent focused on lack of proximate causation, not on whether defendants’ acts and omissions were unreasonable or constituted a breach of duty. In fact, the dissent expressly accepts that there was evidence of negligence (e.g., inadequate locking system) but concludes plaintiff failed to prove that such negligence caused her injury. Thus, this citation does not provide authority that defendants breached the duty of care; it disputes liability on causation grounds.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll.*, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "I agree that the jury could have found that the system for locking the room door was inadequate due to the defendants’ negligence, but I do not agree that the jury could have found that entry into the room was gained by disengaging a lock. … In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor."

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and related damages. *Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion rejects, rather than accepts, the plaintiffs’ claim that the defendant’s negligence caused their injuries. The court affirms summary judgment because plaintiffs offered only speculation about why the scaffolding collapsed and thus could not establish causation—an essential element of negligence. This case is authority for the need to prove causation, not for a finding that defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of plaintiffs’ injuries.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs…failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty to them… These unsubstantiated conjectures cannot support any claim that some property defect chargeable to the defendant caused (or even contributed) to the collapse of the scaffolding.”
